Award.AwardTitle: Inferring Probabilities from Symmetries: Maxwell and Beyond

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support research on the work of the Scottish physicist James Clerk Maxwell. In 1859 Maxwell proposed an important hypothesis for the foundations of statistical mechanics concerning the distribution of positions and velocities of the molecules of a gas; it is known as Maxwell distribution. He had no empirical data indicating that such a distribution existed, let alone that it took the mathematical form that he suggested. Yet his hypothesis proved to be correct, and still serves as an essential element of statistical physics. Maxwell made an enormously important and entirely correct deduction about the behavior of the physical world, then, on the basis of no evidence whatsoever.

This project aims to determine how Maxwell came to formulate that hypothesis. It will do so, first, by showing that Maxwell's inference is based on hypothesized physical symmetries in molecular dynamics; second, by investigating similar apparently a priori probabilistic inferences in other branches of the sciences; and third, by uncovering a general technique, followed by Maxwell and others, for inferring physical probability distributions from physical symmetries. The methods of the project are diverse: a close reading of Maxwell's writings on the probability distribution; an investigation of nineteenth century philosophical commentary on inferences such as Maxwell's; an examination of contemporary psychological research on inferences about physical probability in everyday contexts, especially as found in young children and infants; and most important, an independent investigation of what inferential techniques might possibly succeed in inferring facts about probability from physical symmetries in the absence of corroborating statistical evidence.

A successful completion of the project will provide, among other things, a better understanding of a certain kind of scientific reasoning, a better understanding of certain episodes in the history of scientific discovery (exemplified by Maxwell's great achievement), and a better understanding of certain important aspects of everyday thinking in which there is reasoning, discovery, and cognition involving the inference of probabilities from symmetries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When you look at a coin toss and see that the chances of getting heads and tails are equal (if the coin is well-balanced), you "eyeball" a physical probability. Because you get the value of this probability right, you can predict what will happen if the coin is tossed many times -- you will very likely see about one-half heads and one-half tails. This ability to predict what a system will do by making a "seat of the pants" estimate based on a few facts about the structure of the system is a species of what scientists call "physical intuition".

This project supported the research and writing of a book about "eyeballing" probabilities, or as I prefer to say, about humans' ability to infer physical probabilities from facts about physical structure, as when we infer a one-half probability for heads from the balanced composition of the coin and the way in which it is tossed.

The first part of the book argues that structure-to-probability inferences have played and continue to play an important role in science (as you might not expect from the rather uninteresting case of the coin toss). The invention of statistical physics, I show, turned on physical intuitions about the probabilistic properties of molecular motion, since at the time of the theory's creation, there were no techniques for measuring molecular motion directly. The invention of evolutionary theory likewise hinged on the ability of Darwin and others to make judgments about which traits were more likely and which less likely to increase an organism's probability of surviving or reproducing. The validity of these judgments seemed obvious to Darwin, just as the validity of our judgment that the probability of heads is one-half seems obvious to us, but closer inspection shows that, in order to make such inferences, a considerable amount of reasoning must be going on behind the scenes.

The second part of the book advances a hypothesis about the nature of this reasoning. It proposes six rules that, working sometimes independently and sometimes together, underlie a great part of humans' ability to infer the values of physical probabilities from causal facts without knowing any relevant statistics. The book shows that the rules are capable of explaining structure-to-probability inferences in both adults, most importantly scientists, and in young children -- citing recent work in developmental psychology showing that children have some of the same sort of physical intuition about probability as adults.

The book will make contributions to three areas: the philosophical study of scientific reasoning; the historical understanding of how certain theoretical innovations (in statistical physics and evolutionary biology in particular) were accomplished; and the psychological investigation of the nature of human reasoning about physical probability in infants and adults. It will also help scientists themselves to understand better the nature of one aspect of their physical intuition.
